The dehydrogenative coupling (DHC) of ethanol to ethyl acetate (EA) provides an attractive means for producing a usable energy carrier from stored liquid hydrogen but relies on achieving a high selectivity to EA compared to acetaldehyde – the primary product resulting from ethanol dehydrogenation. We show herein how EA selectivity on copper catalysts increases as the proximity between the dehydrogenation and acid catalytic functions increase both at the catalyst particle as well as the reactor scale. Kinetic tests with trifluoro analogs suggest that ethanol DHC proceeds through the dehydrogenation of hemiacetal species formed from the condensation of ethanol with acetaldehyde formed as a primary product. The zirconia support is shown to be key to producing EA, the selectivity to which can be maximized by making the dehydrogenative function (i.e. copper) proximal to the acid catalytic function i.e. ZrO2. These proximity effects extend over a wide length scales from millimeters in segregated beds comprised of Cu/SiO2 and ZrO2 to angstroms in an extended Cu-Zr oxide sample that exhibits the highest EA selectivity of the samples tested. These results capture the importance of engineering metal-oxide interfaces for improving selectivity to desired products in multifunctional cascades of relevance to the energy transition. Graphical Abstract Keywords Liquid organic hydrogen carriers Dehydrogenative coupling Interfacial effects Data Availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Liquid organic hydrogen carrier (LOHC) molecules provide a means for efficiently storing and transporting hydrogen [1] through the use of exothermic hydrogenation and endothermic dehydrogenation cycles [2]. Ethanol has emerged as a viable LOHC candidate owing to its non-toxicity and non-corrosivity, widespread availability from biomass, and high liquefaction temperature [3]. A critical determinant of the viability of ethanol as an LOHC molecule is our ability to dehydrogenatively couple to ethyl acetate (EA), rather than dehydrogenate to acetaldehyde, given that the latter is a carcinogenic product with a low boiling point and auto-ignition temperature [4]. EA, on the other hand, is relatively benign and has higher boiling and ignition points that are closer to that of ethanol [5,6]. Copper-based catalysts have been heavily considered for ethanol DHC, and strategies for improving EA selectivity including exploiting the identity [7] and phase of the support [8], metal-metal oxide interactions [7], acid-base sites [9], the oxidation state of Cu [10], and the size of Cu nanoparticles have all been explored previously in the literature. Gallo and coworkers studied different supports and found EA selectivity trends as follows: SiO2 < Cr2O3 < Al2O3 < ZnO ≈ ZrO2 [7]. Similarly, when acid and base sites were determined for such metal oxide-supported copper catalysts, Cu/ZrO2 showed the highest EA yield as it possessed an optimal balance of Lewis acid and base sites suitable for the chemistry [9]. The Dumesic group synthesized various samples with different Zr/Cu molar ratios supported over SiO2 and found that EA turnover frequencies (TOFs) correlated positively with the amount of Cu-O-Zr interfacial sites [11]. Sato et al. reported on the vital role of Cu+/Cu0 pairs and interfacial Cu0 for effecting ethanol DHC [10]. Specifically, Cu-zirconia catalysts have been studied extensively for this chemistry [8–11]. Optimal temperature control during calcination, at around 350°C, is key as higher calcination temperatures can transform amorphous zirconia to tetragonal zirconia and cause sintering of copper [12]. The presence of Cu+ species has also been identified as being critical to maximizing catalytic activity, [10,13] often achieved through co-precipitation techniques that enhance copper dispersion while impacting its incorporation into the ZrO2 lattice; this aspect has been investigated heavily for the hydrogenation of CO2 to methanol [12,14,15]. Maximizing the Cu-Zr interfacial area has also been proposed as a means for enhancing catalyst activity, selectivity, and stability [16,17]. The reaction pathway for ethanol DHC to EA on supported copper catalysts has also been studied both experimentally and computationally, with proposed pathways proceeding through acetaldehyde formation via a dehydrogenation step. Inui et al. concluded that the nucleophilic addition of ethanol to acetaldehyde generates a hemiacetal intermediate, which undergoes subsequent dehydrogenation to yield EA over Cu-Zn-Zr-Al-O catalysts [18–20]. Colley et al., on the other hand, suggested that adsorbed acetaldehyde is further dehydrogenated to form an acetyl species, followed by its coupling with an ethoxy species generated from ethanol to produce EA over Cu/Cr2O3 [21]. The Colley and Inui mechanisms were proposed to operate on distinct catalysts – Cu/Cr2O3 and Cu-Zn-Zr-Al-O, respectively. Part of what makes it challenging to derive mechanistic conclusions is the fact that key intermediates such as acetyl or hemiacetal species have not been observed experimentally. In this work, we evaluate the reaction pathways that mediate the dehydrogenative coupling of ethanol to EA over copper-zirconia catalysts. Trifluoro compounds are used to provide evidence for the occurrence of a hemiacetal-mediated pathway and an array of bed configurations is used to show that EA selectivity increases with the proximity of the redox and acid-catalytic functions. Although interfacial effects have previously been postulated for this chemistry, proximity effects, including the role of intermediate product diffusion length and timescales have not, to the best of our knowledge, been clearly demonstrated. Substitution of dopants into the oxide matrix is shown to be a meaningful strategy for maximizing the preponderance of acid-catalyzed chemistry and EA formation rates. The results presented point to the distance between the two functions as being a critical determinant of EA selectivity – a key metric for the viability of ethanol as an LOHC molecule. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Catalyst synthesis t-ZrO2 was prepared using hydrothermal synthesis at 200°C under autogenous pressure for 20 hours in a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave (100 ml) containing an 80 ml solution of 5.7631 g of Urea (99.3 %, Thermo Scientific) and 5.1257 g of Zirconium (IV) Oxynitrate Hydrate (ZrO(NO3)2.xH2O; x ∼ 6 > 36.3 % ZrO2, Sigma-Aldrich) previously stirred at 600 RPM for 1 h with 75 ml of anhydrous methanol (CH3OH, >99.9 %, Macron Fine Chemicals). The precipitate resulting from this hydrothermal synthesis was vacuum filtered and washed thoroughly three times with 50 ml of anhydrous methanol each time and dried overnight at 110°C in a drying oven under ambient air and calcined at 400°C for 4 hours under a 400 sccm flow of air (Air, Ultra Zero, Matheson Gas) to yield t-ZrO2 [22]. The CuO/t-ZrO2 catalyst was synthesized by mixing 1 g of the calcined t-ZrO2 sample with 50 ml of a methanolic solution of 0.4067 g Copper d(II) Nitrate Hemi(pentahydrate) (Cu(NO3)2.2.5H2O, > 99.99 %; Aldrich Chemistry) (with a target copper loading of 10 wt% in the final Cu/t-ZrO2 sample post reduction) and stirred at 600 RPM for 24 hours at ambient temperature. The sample was then dried at 110°C in an oven and calcined at 400°C under a 400 sccm stream of air for 4 hours. 5.019 g of silica (SiO2, Silica gel, Davisil Grade 646, 35–60 mesh, pore size 150, >99 % Sigma-Aldrich) was added to a 50 ml aqueous solution of 2.034 g of Cu(NO3)2.2.5H2O and stirred at ambient temperature for 24 hours at 600 RPM. The copper weight loading was kept the same as the CuO/t-ZrO2 sample. The mixture was then heated overnight in an oven at 110°C. The dried sample was calcined at 400°C under 400 sccm air for 4 hours. A physical mixture of the two samples, referred to as intrapellet mixtures, was prepared by mixing CuO/SiO2 and t-ZrO2 powders in a 1:1 wt ratio (i.e. maintaining the same Cu:ZrO2 ratio as of the Cu/t-ZrO2 sample) in a mortar and crushing using a pestle for 25–30 mins to produce a homogeneously mixed fine powder. CuZrOx was synthesized using co-precipitation with the same target Cu:Zr ratio as the impregnated sample. 1.0836 g of Cu(NO3)2.2.5H2O and 7.3373 g of ZrO(NO3)2.xH2O were added to 150 ml of distilled water and were stirred for an hour using a magnetic stirrer. The slight cloudiness of the solution was eliminated by adding 2–3 drops of nitric acid (HNO3, 20 % (v/v) Ricca) to obtain a clear solution. A separate solution was prepared by dissolving 3.1536 g of sodium hydroxide (NaOH, 98 % Thermo Scientific) in 350 ml of distilled water and stirring at 800 RPM. The Cu-Zr nitrate solution was added dropwise to the NaOH solution over the course of 2 hours while stirring at 800 RPM. The solution was aged at ambient temperature for 24 hours under constant stirring, then vacuum filtered, and the precipitate was washed three times with 100 ml of distilled water during each wash. This still-damp precipitate was divided into three 50 ml centrifuge tubes filled with distilled water and centrifuged for 10 minutes at 6000 RPM and the supernatant was discarded. This centrifugation step was repeated a total of 5 times to ensure the removal of any residual Na+ ions. The washed sample was collected and dried in an oven at 110°C overnight, followed by calcination at 300°C under a 400 sccm flow of air for 4 h. Amorphous zirconia (a-ZrO2) was synthesized using the same procedure as the CuZrOx sample, except that only 7.3373 g of ZrO(NO3)2.xH2O dissolved in 150 ml of distilled water was used during precipitation with aqueous NaOH containing 2.5946 g NaOH with 350 ml distilled water. The aging, vacuum filtration, centrifugation, drying, and calcination steps were kept the same as for the CuZrOx powder. 2.2 Materials characterization The porosity of the samples was assessed using N2 physisorption at 77 K on a Micromeritics 3Flex Surface Characterization Analyzer. Before the measurement, approximately 0.1 g of catalyst sample was evacuated (P ∼ 1 ×10−4 bar) and degassed at 300°C for 3 h. X-ray diffraction (XRD) measurements were obtained using an Empyrean Malvern Panalytical diffractometer equipped with a Cu Kα X-ray source operated at 45 kV and 40 mA. Approximately 0.1 g of finely crushed powder sample was loaded into a glass sample holder before collecting the diffraction pattern in a 5–60° 2-theta value range over 30 minutes. H2 temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) profiles were obtained by first pre-treating 50–100 mg of the fresh sample under a 50 sccm flow of air at 300°C for 2 h, followed by flowing 50 sccm of Helium (He, UHP, >99.99 %, Matheson Gas) for 1 h and cooling back to ambient temperature under He. Next, a mixture of 10 mol% H2/He with 1 sccm of Argon (Ar, >99.99 %, Matheson Gas) as internal standard and a total flow rate of 25 sccm was flown until the H2 and Ar signals (m/z = 2, 40, respectively) on a pre-calibrated MKS Cirrus 3.0 mass spectrometer were stabilized. The temperature was then raised to 300°C at a ramp rate of 5 °C/min and held at 300°C for 2 h while monitoring the H2 consumption rates. Selective oxidation using N2O [23,24] was carried out by first reducing the sample using a 25 sccm flow of 10 mol% H2/He at 300°C for 2 h, then flushing with pure He at 300°C until the H2 signal returned to its baseline value and cooled back the bed to ambient temperature. A stream containing 10 mol% N2O/He (N2O, Research Purity, >99.999 % Matheson Gas) mixture was introduced, and the sample was heated to and held at 90°C for 1 h followed by flushing with pure He for 1 h, then cooled back to ambient temperature under He flow. The sample was back titrated using H2-TPR to measure H2 uptake. The reactions assumed to be involved during the oxidation of Cu(0) to Cu(+1) using N2O, and the back titration TPR are as follows: (1) 2 Cu (s) + N2O (g) → Cu2O (s) + N2 (g) (2) Cu2O (s) + H2 (g) → 2 Cu (s) + H2O (g) Copper dispersion [25] (DCu) was calculated from the amount of H2 consumed in the s-TPR experiment (nH2 mol H2 gcat −1), and the Cu loading in the catalyst (nCu mol Cu gcat −1) using the following relationship: (3) D Cu ( % ) = 2 n H 2 n Cu × 100 In-situ Fourier Transmission Infrared (FTIR) spectroscopy experiments were conducted on a Nicolet iS50 FTIR (Thermo Scientific) spectrometer with a Harrick Dewar Transmission/Reflection Accessory equipped with BaF2 windows (25 ×2, 32 ×3 mm) used to collect spectra averaging 64 scans at a 4 cm−1 resolution in the 720–4000 cm−1 range. An empty cell reference (collected after purging with Ar) was used as a background reference. The catalyst sample mixed with dry KBr (10:90 wt ratio) was pressed into 100 mg self-supporting wafers and was thermally treated at 300°C under a 50 sccm Ar flow, followed by reduction under a 50 sccm flow of 10 mol% H2/Ar for 1 h at the same temperature. The sample was purged with pure Argon (50 sccm) for another hour at 300°C, and then cooled down to ambient temperature and subjected to a 50 sccm flow of 5 mol% CO/Ar (Carbon Monoxide, UHP, >99.9 %, Matheson Gas) mixture for 1 h, followed by a 50 sccm Ar flow for 1 h to desorb physiosorbed CO. Infrared spectra were collected after the Ar purge when there was no change in the CO adsorption peak intensity with respect to time. Infrared spectra collected here were replicated using three different catalyst samples and reported without normalization. 2.3 Catalytic tests Ethanol dehydrogenation kinetics were measured on a continuous-flow, fixed-bed quartz tube reactor (4 mm inner diameter) setup. Experiments were conducted at atmospheric pressure over a 150–300°C temperature range. Kinetic data reported here were measured after maintaining steady state for at least 2 hours. Catalyst samples were crushed using a mortar and pestle, pelletized at 10,000 psi using a hydraulic press, and crushed and sieved to obtain particle sizes ranging between 180 and 425 µm (40–80 mesh size). The sample was pretreated in situ under a 10 mol% H2/He mixture at 300°C, followed by purging under inert before being subjected to the corresponding reaction conditions. Ethanol (Ethanol, Anhydrous, 200 Proof, KOPTEC) was introduced using a Hamilton gastight liquid injection syringe housed in a KD Scientific Syringe Pump. Ethanol was vaporized using heating tape around the liquid inlet line maintained at around 180°C. Helium was used as diluent and methane (CH4, >99.99 %, UHP, Matheson Gas) as the internal standard. Condensation of reactants and products was avoided by using heating tape to maintain bypass and reactant lines at around 180°C. The catalyst sample was held in place in the quartz tube using quartz wool and was heated using an Applied Test System (ATS) furnace, with the temperature being measured using a K-type thermocouple positioned axially on top of the catalyst bed. The upstream bed pressure was measured using an Omega Engineering pressure transducer (range: 0–1000 psig) connected to a strain gauge panel meter (DP25B-S). The bypass and effluent streams were analyzed using an Agilent 7890B Gas Chromatograph (GC) equipped with both a thermal conductivity detector (TCD) and a flame ionization detector (FID). An HP-PLOT Q GC column of 30 m length, 320 µm diameter, and 20 µm film thickness was used to separate the products. EA selectivity was calculated using the following equation: (4) % Ethyl Acetate Selectivity = 2 × F EtOAc ∑ n i , EtOH × F i × 100 % where Fi represents the molar flowrate of product i and ni,EtOH indicates the number of molecules of ethanol needed to form product i based on the stoichiometry of the reaction. The selectivity to C4+ products, including methyl ethyl ketone, 1-butanol, and crotonaldehyde was combined with that of acetone and unidentified products and reported under the category 'Rest'. The ethanol dehydrogenation rate (rDH) normalized by the moles of accessible copper (mCu) in the catalyst determined using N2O selective oxidation was calculated as follows: (5) r DH = F AcH + F EtOAc + Σ n i , EtOH × F i , Rest n Cu 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization Three types of copper catalysts were evaluated in this study – silica-supported copper (Cu/SiO2), zirconia-supported copper (Cu/t-ZrO2), and extended copper-zirconium oxide (CuZrOx). The silica-supported samples had much higher surface areas and pore volumes compared to the zirconia-supported samples ( Table 1). The intrapellet mixture, as expected, possesses a surface area intermediate between those of Cu/SiO2 and t-ZrO2. The adsorption isotherms are reported in SI. (Figure S1 a-c). The t-ZrO2-containing samples exhibited diffraction peaks at 2θ values of 30.3, 35.2, 50.4, and 60.2° ( Fig. 1a) that can be assigned to the (101), (110), (112), and (211) planes of t-ZrO2 (JCPDS 88–1007). Diffraction peaks for monoclinic or cubic zirconia were absent, suggesting that the synthesized support contained only the tetragonal crystalline phase. Diffraction peaks related to CuO were not observed in the calcined CuO/t-ZrO2 sample but were observed at very low intensity in the reduced Cu/t-ZrO2 sample. These diffraction peaks reflect copper oxide domains that arise when the reduced sample comes in contact with air, and the peak at a 2θ value of 38.7° can be attributed to the (111) crystal plane of monoclinic CuO with a tenorite structure (JCPDS 48–1548). Impregnation of Cu followed by calcination produced two peaks assigned to the monoclinic phase of zirconia at a 2θ value of 31.5 and a shoulder at 34.2° (JCPDS 86–1450). Of these diffraction peaks, the shoulder at 31.5° increased in intensity after reduction for the Cu/t-ZrO2 sample. Metallic Cu particles (Cu/t-ZrO2) showed a minor bump at a 2θ value of 43.3° that can be assigned to the (111) crystal face of metallic copper (JCPDS 04–0836). The amorphous zirconia sample a-ZrO2, as expected, carries very broad, low-intensity diffraction peaks (Fig. 1b). The extended copper-zirconia catalyst CuZrOx, just like the a-ZrO2 sample, shows very broad peaks, suggesting a lack of crystalline ZrO2. The sample, once reduced, however, results in the formation of crystalline metallic copper, as evidenced by (111) and (200) peaks at 43.3° and 50.5°, respectively. The silica support used was also found to be amorphous (Fig. 1c), with the corresponding CuO and Cu diffraction peaks appearing upon calcination and reduction of the copper-containing sample, respectively. H2-TPR profiles for the silica and zirconia-supported copper catalysts were highly contrasting in form ( Fig. 2). Whereas CuO/SiO2 exhibited one wide peak at 490 K with a shoulder at 460 K, the CuO/t-ZrO2 sample exhibited a low-temperature peak at 428 K. The reduction feature at 428 K has been ascribed to well-dispersed Cu oxide species [10], indicating a weak CuO-ZrO2 interaction. The 460 and 490 K peaks could be assigned to the reduction of CuO due to strong interaction with the ZrO2 surface or bulk CuO [13]. CuO/t-ZrO2 exhibits a significant peak at 428 K and a minor one at 460 K, indicating that most of the copper is well-dispersed over the t-ZrO2 support and a small fraction is bulk CuO. CuZrOx showed a similar reduction profile as CuO/SiO2 with a broad peak ranging between 450 and 500 K. This high reduction temperature of CuZrOx might indicate that the Cu is incorporated into the a-ZrO2 lattice, rendering the reduction more challenging. Copper dispersion values measured using N2O chemisorption on pre-reduced samples are reported in Table 1. These data clearly show that the surface area of the support affects copper dispersion, with larger surface area supports resulting in better dispersion of copper. The unsupported copper sample CuZrOx exhibits a much higher dispersion compared to the supported CuO/t-ZrO2 sample (32 versus 6.5 %) – a fact that will be critical in interpreting its ethanol DHC performance that will be discussed in later sections. In-situ infrared spectroscopy with adsorbed CO was used to assess the oxidation state distribution of copper [26]. CO adsorption onto copper results in infrared bands in the 2000–2200 cm−1 wavenumber region [11]. Fig. 3 shows in-situ FTIR spectra in the presence of adsorbed CO at 303 K for Cu/t-ZrO2, CuZrOx, and mixed beds containing pellets of t-ZrO2 and Cu/SiO2. For all three samples, a band is noted at 2115 cm−1, with a clear shoulder appearing at 2135 cm−1. The band at 2115 cm−1 has been assigned to CO adsorbed on metallic copper (Cu(0)), and that at 2135 cm−1 to CO bound on partially oxidized copper (Cuδ+ or Cu+1) [10]. Deconvolution of the spectra provides us with the fraction of accessible copper that is present in either oxidation state. The fraction of Cuδ+-CO in the Cu/SiO2, Cu/t-ZrO2, and CuZrOx samples, respectively, are 46.7, 51.6, and 69.9 %. The partial positive charge on these copper sites has been suggested to be associated with neighboring Lewis acid sites such as Zr4+ from the zirconia support that have a strong nucleophilicity towards 4 s1 electrons of Cu(0) atoms [11]. The presence of partially oxidized copper at the interface would be consistent with the larger fraction of Cuδ+ in the CuZrOx sample that has a higher copper dispersion compared to the Cu/t-ZrO2 sample. The unexpectedly large fraction of Cuδ+ in the intrapellet mixture may be a consequence of the high copper dispersion value and the small size of copper domains on this material. XPS measurements on pre-reduced samples that were partially oxidized under N2O showed little difference in the distribution of oxidation states for the three samples (refer SI, section S.9.). 3.2 Ethanol DHC reaction pathway Scheme 1 shows a map of the reactions that ethanol can undergo on Cu/ZrO2 catalysts. Ethanol can undergo dehydration– either unimolecular dehydration to form ethylene or bimolecular dehydration to form diethyl ether. Both these dehydration reactions are termination steps in that they result in products that do not undergo secondary reactions to form EA. Alternatively, ethanol can dehydrogenate to acetaldehyde, which can either dimerize or couple with ethanol to produce EA. Acetaldehyde is verified to be a primary product as extrapolation to 0 % ethanol conversion indicates an initial selectivity of almost 100 % for both Cu/t-ZrO2 and CuZrOx. Also, EA is formed at the expense of acetaldehyde with increasing ethanol conversion (Figures S3 and S4, SI). Water produced as a byproduct of dehydration can hydrolyze EA to acetic acid, although no acetic acid was observed in the product stream. Apart from the desired route to produce EA, acetaldehyde can also undergo aldol condensation to form acetaldol, which can either dehydrate to produce crotonaldehyde or undergo a series of hydrogen transfer and condensation reactions [27] to yield 1-butanol and 2-butanone (i.e. methyl ethyl ketone or MEK). One of the intermediates – 4-hydroxy-2-butanone – can decompose to acetone and formaldehyde. Although many of these products are observed in our experiments, the sum of selectivities to ethylene, diethyl ether, and ethane were less than 1 % at 200°C (carbon balances provided in the SI, Table S2). COx formation was also found to be insignificant. Selectivity-conversion data for the Cu/t-ZrO2 sample between 150 and 300°C is plotted in section S.2. of the Supporting Information. In this study, we focus on the desired steps that produce EA in this overall reaction network and attempt to understand the mechanism by which ethanol DHC occurs on copper catalysts. Scheme 2 enumerates the various possible routes for EA formation from ethanol. Acetaldehyde formed in primary ethanol dehydrogenation (R1) can form EA through three distinct routes: the acetyl, Tishchenko, and hemiacetal routes. Acetaldehyde, in the acetyl route, dehydrogenates to acetyl (CH3CO-) intermediate that couples with an ethoxy species to yield EA (R5). The Tishchenko pathway involves the coupling of two acetaldehyde molecules through the Tishchenko reaction. The hemiacetal route proceeds through the nucleophilic addition of acetaldehyde to ethanol (R2) to form hemiacetal, which undergoes further dehydrogenation to EA, either unimolecularly (R3), or bimolecularly through transfer dehydrogenation (or Meerwein–Ponndorf–Verley reduction) with acetaldehyde (R4). The plausibility of the Tishchenko pathway was evaluated by testing the reactivity of acetaldehyde in the absence of ethanol. EA was completely absent from the product stream when 0.06 kPa acetaldehyde (Acetaldehyde, ACS reagent, >99.5 %, Sigma-Aldrich) was fed over the 53.2 mg of Cu/t-ZrO2 at 200°C. A 9.6 % conversion of acetaldehyde was achieved, and crotonaldehyde (68.1 %) and MEK (13.5 %) were the only identifiable products formed ( Table 2). The unidentified products likely result from the oligomerization of acetaldehyde over acid sites present on the t-ZrO2 surface and some of these products remain on the oxide surface, as verified by heating the bed to 400°C post-reaction under helium and oxidizing with 10 % O2/He. Exposure to oxygen at 400°C results in CO2 that is formed from the combustion of oligomerized debris (Section S4, Figure S5). This polymerization chemistry appears to be affected by the zirconia surface given that similar acetaldehyde conversions were obtained when feeding acetaldehyde over copper-free t-ZrO2 (8.7 % acetaldehyde conversion, 89.3 % crotonaldehyde, and 5.6 % MEK), and negligible (less than 0.5 %) conversions were achieved for the same experiment on a Cu/SiO2 bed. Based on the complete absence of EA in these tests, we rule out the Tishchenko pathway for EA formation (R6). To test whether the hemiacetal pathway is operative on these catalysts, ethanol, and acetaldehyde were cofed in a 1:0.17 molar ratio over t-ZrO2 at 5 kPa ethanol. The absence of copper ensures a lack of ethanol dehydrogenation (Section 3.3), and 27, 46, and 27 % of the product carbon was found to be in the form of hemiacetal, EA, and C4+ oxygenates, respectively ( Table 3). These reactivity data point to the fact that all steps required for EA formation, including hemiacetal formation, can occur on the zirconia surface. EA formation can occur either through the unimolecular dehydrogenation of hemiacetal (R3), or the transfer dehydrogenation/MPV reduction of hemiacetal with acetaldehyde (R4). In comparison, a 5 kPa feed of ethanol yielding a product AcH: EtOH molar ratio of 0.18: 1 over Cu/t-ZrO2 results in 16.2 % conversion of ethanol – 89.3 % to EA and 10.7 % to C4s+ on an acetaldehyde-free basis. EA formation rate per gram t-ZrO2 is much higher for the copper-containing catalyst compared to the copper-free sample (3.741 ×10−5 mol/gt-ZrO2/min for Cu/t-ZrO2 versus 6.456 ×10−6 mol/gt-ZrO2/min for the bare t-ZrO2), suggesting that copper facilitates dehydrogenation of the hemiacetal intermediate and that the conversion of acetaldehyde to EA is limited not by hemiacetal formation but by its decomposition. Copper-mediated hemiacetal dehydrogenation predominates to an extent where hemiacetal was only detectable in experiments over bare t-ZrO2, not Cu/t-ZrO2. Given the unstable nature of the hemiacetal intermediate, we used the trifluoro analog of hemiacetal to further investigate the EA formation pathway. Trifluoro acetaldehyde ethyl hemiacetal (>80.0 %, ca 10 % Ethanol, TCI Chemicals)– an analog of the hemiacetal species formed during ethanol conversion – was cofed with ethanol over t-ZrO2, Cu/t-ZrO2, and Cu/SiO2 beds. Ethyl trifluoroacetate formation rates increase monotonically with trifluoro acetaldehyde co-feed pressure for all three catalysts ( Fig. 4), consistent with EA formation resulting from hemiacetal dehydrogenation. The rates of ester formation per gram of catalyst were similar for Cu/t-ZrO2 and t-ZrO2, but much lower for the Cu/SiO2 sample that had a much higher dispersion of copper, indicating that the support plays a critical role in hemiacetal dehydrogenation, and that zirconia supports promote the desired chemistry to form EA. The increasing values of trifluoroester formation rates with trifluorohemiacetal pressure over the Cu/SiO2 catalyst that has no acid sites that participate in EA formation indicate that trifluoro hemiacetal can decompose back to trifluoroacetaldehyde and form the ester by coupling with ethanol in the feed through the acetyl-ethoxy coupling pathway over Cu sites (R5). Hemi ] where k is the lumped rate constant for trifluorohemiacetal decomposition, and K is the equilibrium constant for its adsorption onto the catalyst surface ( Table 4). 3.3 Active site requirements and proximity effects The higher rates of EA formation on Cu/t-ZrO2 compared to Cu/SiO2, combined with the comparable rates of trifluoro acetaldehyde ethyl hemiacetal dehydrogenation over Cu/t-ZrO2 and bare t-ZrO2 catalysts suggests that ethanol dehydrogenation occurs on copper surfaces, hemiacetal formation occurs on Cu-t-ZrO2 interfaces, and hemiacetal dehydrogenation occurs over t-ZrO2 surfaces. Such bifunctionality in catalytic function points to the proximity between copper and zirconia acid sites as being critical to maximizing EA selectivity. To further explore proximity effects, we tested copper catalysts in a series of bed configurations in which diffusion length scales between the ethanol dehydrogenation function, i.e. copper, and the hemiacetal dehydrogenation function, i.e. t-ZrO2, are varied ( Fig. 5). The first experiment involved bare t-ZrO2 in the absence of any copper content. Very low ethanol conversions (0.78 %) were achieved on this catalyst, likely due to the high barrier for βC–H scission [28] under these reaction conditions. Cu/SiO2 resulted in higher ethanol conversions (35 %), but only limited EA selectivity (1.5 %), consistent with the expectation that silica supports do not provide the requisite acid sites for acetaldehyde conversion to EA. Also, the dehydrogenation TOFs measured on Cu/SiO2 at 35 % ethanol conversion is 0.2857 s−1, similar to the 0.3018 s−1 value measured over Cu/t-ZrO2 at identical conditions, suggesting that ethanol dehydrogenation to acetaldehyde (R1) occurs solely on copper clusters and that the support has minimal impact on this reaction. Selectivity to other C4 + oxygenates was only 2.03 %, suggesting that the silica support doesn’t facilitate the aldolization chemistry that produces undesired products either. The small amount of EA produced on Cu/SiO2 may be formed by the reaction of adsorbed ethoxide (CH3CH2O–Cu+1) and acetyl (CH3CO–Cu(0)) species (R5 in Scheme 2).21 Next, we tested a stacked bed configuration in which Cu/SiO2 and t-ZrO2 beds were separated by a plug of quartz wool. Given the minute selectivity to EA observed on the Cu/SiO2 catalyst, the t-ZrO2 bed placed downstream is expected to convert the acetaldehyde formed on copper sites to EA. The selectivity to EA at 35 % ethanol conversion increased from 1.5 % in the bed without t-ZrO2 placed downstream of the silica bed to 3.5 % in the stacked-bed configuration, evidencing the propensity of t-ZrO2 toward converting acetaldehyde to EA through the hemiacetal pathway. This configuration increased not only the EA selectivity but also the formation of other C4 + compounds (10.2 % selectivity), indicating that apart from catalyzing the desired conversion of acetaldehyde to EA, acid sites on the t-ZrO2 support also catalyze the aldolization chemistry that produces undesired products. To further increase proximity between the dehydrogenation function i.e. copper, and the acid catalytic and hemiacetal dehydrogenation function i.e. zirconia, the Cu/SiO2 and t-ZrO2 pellets were mixed into a single bed, thereby reducing the distance between the two sets of sites from millimeters to hundreds of microns. For this interpellet mixture configuration, where every pellet of Cu/SiO2 was discrete but in contact with the t-ZrO2 pellets, the EA selectivity was maintained at 3.7 % and increased the C4 + selectivity from 10.2 % to 14.7 %, similar to the aforementioned stacked-bed configuration. Bringing these two moieties even closer together by creating pellets containing both Cu/SiO2 and t-ZrO2 particles (intrapellet mixtures) also has little effect on EA selectivity (4.0 %), but lowers the aldolization chemistry selectivity from 14.7 % to 11.35 %. The Cu/t-ZrO2 bed, unlike these Cu/SiO2 - t-ZrO2 combinations, contains a Cu-Zr interface and reduces acetaldehyde diffusion length scales to molecular regimes, therefore resulting in a significantly higher selectivity to EA (20.2 %) than the Cu/SiO2 - t-ZrO2 combinations (3.5 – 4 %). This result captures the need for Cu-Zr interfaces in promoting reaction pathways that produce EA because a reduction in diffusion length scales from millimeters in the case of the stacked bed configuration to less than tens of microns in the case of the intrapellet mixed bed results in an imperceptibly small difference in EA selectivity, but the creation of an interface between the two functions by impregnating the zirconia support with copper results in a more than 5-fold increase in EA selectivity at 35 % ethanol conversion. C4 + formation rates are also lower on the impregnated copper catalyst (8.06 % for Cu/t-ZrO2 versus 10.2–14.7 % for the mixed bed configurations), possibly due to the poisoning of acid sites by copper. The fraction of interfacial copper can be further maximized by dispersing the metal in an extended oxide through co-precipitation using copper and zirconium nitrate precursors. The CuZrOx sample synthesized using co-precipitation was the most selective of the catalysts tested in our study, with the EA selectivity at 35 % ethanol conversion being almost twice the value for the impregnated sample (37.5 versus 20.2 %). The CuZrOx sample also has a better balance of acid and base sites (Section S.11, SI), analogous to previous studies that have shown improvements in esterification selectivity in the co-presence of acid and base sites [9], unlike in cases where an excess of acid sites promotes undesirable C-C coupling reactions [29]. These data collectively reinforce the importance of copper-zirconia interfaces in maximizing EA selectivity and suggest that extended copper-zirconium oxides may be promising candidates for the selective dehydrogenative coupling of ethanol to EA. Figs. 6 and 7 The rates of ethanol dehydrogenation (R1) and acetaldehyde esterification (R2) were analyzed quantitatively to capture these interfacial effects. The rates of these two reactions were measured as a function of ethanol pressure (PEtOH), and the forward rate (ri,f) was calculated by correcting the net rate (ri,Net) by the approach to equilibrium (ηi) (Figures S6 and S7) using the following equation: (7) r i , f = r i , Net ( 1 − η i ) The dehydrogenation reaction followed a fractional positive order in ethanol, and was regressed to the following rate expression that assumed ethanol to be the most abundant surface intermediate, (8) r 1 = k 1 K EtOH P EtOH [ 1 + K EtOH P EtOH ] where k1 is the lumped rate constant for dehydrogenation, and KEtOH is the equilibrium constant for ethanol adsorption. The kinetics of acetaldehyde-ethanol coupling to form EA (R2) can in principle be measured directly by feeding high acetaldehyde:ethanol molar ratios, but the high volatility of acetaldehyde resulted in these mixtures vaporizing inside the syringe, thereby causing an unstable feed flow into the catalyst bed. High acetaldehyde: ethanol molar ratios were therefore instead obtained by using Cu/SiO2 beds. As shown in Figure S8, Cu/SiO2 generates predominantly acetaldehyde as a product, with less than 5 % of the converted ethanol forming EA and other C4 products. Varying ethanol partial pressures into the Cu/SiO2 bed were used to produce feeds with different acetaldehyde: ethanol molar ratios ranging between 0.5 and 3.3. The same three beds – Cu/t-ZrO2, CuZrOx, and intrapellet mixtures – were placed downstream of the Cu/SiO2 bed used to generate these acetaldehyde-ethanol mixtures, and the coupling rates calculated as a function of ethanol and acetaldehyde pressure. EA formation rates were first order in acetaldehyde and zero order in ethanol for all three beds (Section S7, Figure S9 a-c), and were regressed against the following rate expression: (9) r 2 = k 2 P AcH α Table 5 lists the k1 and k2 values obtained by regressing against Eqs. 8 and 9. k1 values are highest for the Cu/t-ZrO2 sample, and lowest for the CuZrOx sample. k2 values, on the other hand, are highest for the Cu/t-ZrO2 sample but lowest for the intrapellet mixed bed, indicating that the two samples containing Cu-Zr interfaces are the ones that provide a greater proportion of sites for the coupling of ethanol and acetaldehyde. The k2/k1 ratio for CuZrOx is 2.4 times that of Cu/t-ZrO2, indicating that the CuZrOx sample obtained through co-precipitation, although less active for dehydrogenation on a per mol surface Cu basis when compared to Cu/t-ZrO2, is nevertheless more selective toward EA owing to a larger fraction of the accessible copper being in the vicinity of zirconia surfaces. 4 Conclusions This work proposes a reaction pathway for the non-oxidative dehydrogenative coupling of ethanol to EA over copper catalysts. Kinetic measurements, combined with the use of trifluoromethyl analogs, allow us to identify the hemiacetal pathway as the one that mediates ethanol DHC. The presence of Cu-Zr interfaces is shown to be critical to maximizing EA selectivity, with the CuZrOx sample synthesized through co-precipitation being the most selective to EA. The CuZrOx sample tested here is highly selective, but not the most active ethanol DHC catalyst, and further improvements in reaction rates could readily be obtained by developing synthetic methods to more effectively dope copper into the zirconia matrix. The data presented herein highlight interfacial phenomena and proximity considerations as key factors determining EA production rates in copper-based catalysts for the dehydrogenative coupling of ethanol specifically, and for the upgrading of ethanol to value-added chemical products more generally. coredata.dc:description: The dehydrogenative coupling (DHC) of ethanol to ethyl acetate (EA) provides an attractive means for producing a usable energy carrier from stored liquid hydrogen but relies on achieving a high selectivity to EA compared to acetaldehyde – the primary product resulting from ethanol dehydrogenation. We show herein how EA selectivity on copper catalysts increases as the proximity between the dehydrogenation and acid catalytic functions increase both at the catalyst particle as well as the reactor scale. Kinetic tests with trifluoro analogs suggest that ethanol DHC proceeds through the dehydrogenation of hemiacetal species formed from the condensation of ethanol with acetaldehyde formed as a primary product. The zirconia support is shown to be key to producing EA, the selectivity to which can be maximized by making the dehydrogenative function (i.e. copper) proximal to the acid catalytic function i.e. ZrO2. These proximity effects extend over a wide length scales from millimeters in segregated beds comprised of Cu/SiO2 and ZrO2 to angstroms in an extended Cu-Zr oxide sample that exhibits the highest EA selectivity of the samples tested. These results capture the importance of engineering metal-oxide interfaces for improving selectivity to desired products in multifunctional cascades of relevance to the energy transition.
